{"step_by_step_thinking": "Document [0] states that women of low socioeconomic status were significantly more likely to report unmet learning needs related to 9 of 10 topics compared with women of higher socioeconomic status. Document [1] also mentions that some women's characteristics, such as employment status and educational level, have increased women's concerns and unmet needs in some of the learning needs. Document [3] mentions that low SES was associated with increased depressive symptoms in late pregnancy and at 2 and 3 months, but not at 1 month postpartum. Document [11] also mentions that immigrant women were significantly more likely than Canadian-born women to have low family incomes, low social support, poorer health, possible postpartum depression, learning needs that were unmet in hospital, and a need for financial assistance. All these documents suggest that socioeconomic status does matter in the learning needs of postpartum women.", "answer_choice": "A"}
